reading_comprehension_problems.passage: In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations. This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 목적으로 가장 적절한 것은?

options.text: to explain that skills and intelligence are shaped by one's environment
to criticize the lack of practical skills in Western education
to introduce the adventures of the scientist Jared Diamond
to provide survival tips for navigating a jungle
to compare the lifestyles of Westerners and New Guineans

answer.explanation: 이 글은 우리의 경험과 환경이 주의를 기울여야 할 대상을 결정한다고 서두에 밝히고, Jared Diamond와 뉴기니 원주민의 예를 들어 이를 설명합니다. 서구인에게는 서툰 원주민이 정글에서는 뛰어난 능력을 보이고, 반대로 Diamond는 정글에서 무능력하다는 것을 보여줌으로써, 기술과 지능이 절대적인 것이 아니라 각자의 환경에 의해 형성되는 상대적인 것임을 설명하는 것이 이 글의 주된 목적입니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage: In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations. This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 제목으로 가장 적절한 것은?

options.text: What You See Depends on Where You've Been
Jared Diamond: An Explorer of the Modern Age
The Superior Survival Skills of Native Tribes
Dangers of the New Guinea Jungle
How to Train Your Attention for Success

answer.explanation: 이 글의 핵심은 우리의 이전 경험과 환경이 우리가 무엇에 주의를 기울이고 어떤 기술을 갖게 되는지를 결정한다는 것입니다. 뉴기니 원주민은 정글 환경에 맞는 것을 보고 기술을 발전시켰고, 서구인인 Diamond는 그렇지 못했습니다. 따라서 '당신이 무엇을 보는지는 당신이 어디에 있었는지에 달려있다'는 제목이 환경에 따른 인식과 능력의 상대성을 가장 잘 표현합니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage: In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations. This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 요지로 가장 적절한 것은?

options.text: The skills and attentional abilities people develop are profoundly shaped by their specific environmental experiences and needs.
Western education systems fail to teach the practical survival skills that are necessary for living in nature.
Jared Diamond's research proves that native New Guineans possess a higher level of overall intelligence than Westerners.
Anyone can easily learn to survive in a new environment by observing and imitating the local population.
Building a shelter and finding food are the most fundamental skills for human survival in any environment.

answer.explanation: 이 글은 사람들이 발전시키는 기술과 주의력은 그들이 속한 환경에 의해 결정된다는 점을 Jared Diamond의 예시를 통해 보여줍니다. 뉴기니 원주민은 정글 환경의 필요에 맞는 기술을, 서구인은 그들의 환경에 맞는 기술을 가지고 있습니다. 이는 기술과 능력이 절대적인 것이 아니라 환경적 경험과 필요에 의해 깊이 형성된다는 것을 의미합니다. 따라서 '사람들이 발전시키는 기술과 주의력은 그들의 특정한 환경적 경험과 필요에 의해 깊이 형성된다'가 글의 요지입니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage: This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. ( ① ) They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. ( ② ) They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. ( ③ ) Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. ( ④ )
reading_comprehension_problems.question:
글의 흐름으로 보아, 주어진 문장이 들어가기에 가장 적절한 곳은?

**But they are hardly stupid.**

answer.explanation: 주어진 문장은 '하지만 그들은 결코 어리석지 않다'는 의미입니다. 바로 앞 문장에서 뉴기니 원주민들이 서구인들의 과업에는 서툴다고(perform poorly) 언급하여 자칫 그들이 능력이 부족하다고 오해할 수 있습니다. 주어진 문장은 'But'을 통해 이러한 오해를 바로잡고, 이어지는 문장에서 그들이 정글에서 보여주는 놀라운 능력들을 나열하기 위한 전환점 역할을 합니다. 따라서 원주민의 서툰 면모를 언급한 직후이자 그들의 뛰어난 능력을 나열하기 직전인 ①에 들어가는 것이 가장 자연스럽습니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage: In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations.

question_blocks.A: He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid.
question_blocks.B: This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans.
question_blocks.C: They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease.

reading_comprehension_problems.question: 주어진 글 다음에 이어질 글의 순서로 가장 적절한 것은?

answer.explanation: 주어진 글은 '환경이 기대를 만든다'는 일반적인 원칙을 제시합니다. (B)는 'This was profoundly illustrated by...'라며 이 원칙을 뒷받침하는 구체적인 예시(Jared Diamond의 경험)를 도입합니다. (A)는 그 예시의 내용을 설명하기 시작하며, 원주민들이 서구인의 과업에는 서툴지만 어리석지는 않다고 말합니다. (C)는 (A)의 마지막 문장('hardly stupid')에 대한 근거를 제시하며, 원주민들이 가진 구체적인 정글 생존 기술들을 나열합니다. 따라서 '원칙 제시 -> 예시 도입(B) -> 예시 내용 전개(A) -> 예시 부연 설명(C)'의 순서가 가장 논리적입니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage: In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different ____________________. This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 빈칸에 들어갈 말로 가장 적절한 것은?

answer.explanation: 빈칸이 있는 문장은 글의 주제를 제시하는 부분입니다. 글 전체는 다른 환경(정글 vs 서구 사회)이 다른 종류의 기술과 주의력을 만들어낸다는 것을 보여줍니다. 사람들은 자신의 환경에 맞춰 무엇이 중요하고 무엇을 예측해야 할지에 대한 '기대(expectations)'를 형성하게 됩니다. 본문에서 이 문장은 글의 핵심 전제로 직접적으로 제시되었으며, 이어지는 예시가 이 전제를 뒷받침합니다. 따라서 빈칸에는 'expectations'가 가장 적절합니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage: In everyday life, we use previous experience to ① `predict` where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations. ... He relates that these natives tend to perform ② `poorly` at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most ③ `obvious` changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ④ `ease`. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ⑤ `ability` to pay attention to these things.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?

answer.explanation: 이 문장은 뉴기니 원주민들의 뛰어난 능력을 설명하는 부분입니다. 그들이 정글에서 포식자를 추적하거나 집으로 가는 길을 찾는 데 능숙한 이유는 정글의 '미묘한(subtle)' 변화를 감지할 수 있기 때문입니다. '명백한(obvious)' 변화를 감지하는 것은 특별한 기술이 아니므로, 문맥상 그들의 뛰어난 능력을 설명하기에 적절하지 않습니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage: This was (A) `profoundly` illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond... He describes an adventure (B) `wandering` through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. ... They can (C) `detect` the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the (D) `tracks` of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone... can build and tear down shelters with (E) `ease`.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 밑줄 친 (A)~(E)에 대한 영영 풀이가 적절하지 않은 것은?

options.text: (A) profoundly: in a way that is very great or intense
(B) wandering: walking slowly around a place without any particular purpose or direction
(C) detect: to notice or discover something, especially something that is not easy to see, hear, etc.
(D) tracks: a type of road or path that is rough and not paved
(E) ease: the state of experiencing no difficulty or effort

answer.explanation: 본문에서 (D) `tracks`는 포식자의 '발자국'이나 '흔적'을 의미합니다. 하지만 보기 ④의 영영 풀이는 '포장되지 않은 거친 길이나 도로의 한 종류'를 의미하는 'track'에 대한 설명입니다(예: a dirt track). 따라서 문맥상의 의미와 다른 이 풀이는 적절하지 않습니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage: Different environments create (A) [different / similar] expectations. This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond... He relates that these natives tend to perform (B) [poorly / brilliantly] at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly (C) [stupid / skilled]. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장 적절한 것은?

answer.explanation: (A) 글의 핵심 전제는 '다른(different)' 환경이 다른 기대를 만든다는 것입니다. (B) 뉴기니 원주민들은 서구인들의 과업에는 '서툴게(poorly)' 수행한다고 언급됩니다. (C) 하지만 그들은 결코 '어리석지(stupid)' 않으며, 뒤이어 그들의 뛰어난 능력이 나열됩니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage: This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. ① He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. ② The book was first published in 1997 and went on to win the Pulitzer Prize. ③ He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. ④ But they are hardly stupid; they can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle. ⑤
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글에서 전체 흐름과 관계 없는 문장은?

answer.explanation: 이 글은 Jared Diamond의 책 내용을 예시로 들어 '환경이 기술을 만든다'는 주장을 설명하는 것이 목적입니다. ①, ③, ④번 문장은 모두 책의 내용, 즉 Diamond의 경험과 관찰을 인용하며 글의 주제를 뒷받침합니다. 하지만 ②번 문장 '그 책은 1997년에 처음 출판되었고 퓰리처상을 수상했다'는 책의 출판 정보와 수상 경력에 대한 사실로, 책의 '내용'을 통해 주장을 펼치는 글의 흐름과는 직접적인 관련이 없습니다.

reading_comprehension_problems.passage: He relates ① [that / what] these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They know which insects ② [to leave / leaving] alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. ③ [Were he / He were] to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.
reading_comprehension_problems.question: 다음 글의 각 네모 안에서 어법에 맞는 표현으로 가장 적절한 것을 각각 고르시오.

answer.explanation: 동사 'relates'(이야기하다)의 목적어 역할을 하는 명사절이 필요합니다. 뒷부분 'these natives tend to perform poorly...'는 완전한 문장이므로, 접속사 'that'이 와야 합니다. 관계대명사 'what'은 뒤에 불완전한 절을 이끕니다.
의문사(which, what, where 등) 뒤에 to부정사가 오면 '~해야 할지'라는 의미의 명사구로 사용될 수 있습니다. 여기서는 '어떤 곤충을 내버려 두어야 할지'라는 의미로 'know'의 목적어 역할을 하므로 'to leave'가 적절합니다.
이 문장은 가정법 미래(If he were to be tested...)의 if가 생략되면서 주어와 동사가 도치된 형태입니다. 가정법에서 if가 생략될 경우 'be'동사나 조동사가 문장 앞으로 이동합니다. 따라서 'Were he'가 올바른 도치 구문입니다.
